security_audit.summary: Legitimate spreadsheet manipulation skill with controlled subprocess execution for LibreOffice formula recalculation. All subprocess calls use hardcoded commands (soffice) with no user input injection risk. The static findings represent false positives triggered by: (1) Excel cell references like C2 being misinterpreted as C2 malware indicators, (2) documentation text matching security scanner patterns, and (3) legitimate LibreOffice configuration file access. No credential theft, data exfiltration, or malicious patterns detected.

low_findings.title: Subprocess execution for LibreOffice
low_findings.description: The recalc.py script executes the 'soffice' command (LibreOffice) via subprocess.run() at lines 31-32 and 92. This is required for formula recalculation but represents external command execution.

low_findings.title: User config directory file write
low_findings.description: The script writes a LibreOffice macro file to user config directory at lines 46-47. This modifies user configuration but is necessary for formula recalculation.

content.value_statement: Users need to work with spreadsheet data for financial modeling, reporting, and analysis. This skill provides tools to create, modify, and analyze Excel files with full formula support, formatting options, and data visualization capabilities.
actual_capabilities: Create new Excel spreadsheets with formulas, formatting, and styling
Read and analyze data from existing .xlsx, .xlsm, .csv, and .tsv files
Modify spreadsheets while preserving existing formulas and formatting
Perform data analysis using pandas with statistics and visualizations
Recalculate all formulas in spreadsheets using LibreOffice integration
Apply industry-standard color coding and number formatting conventions
limitations: Formula recalculation requires LibreOffice to be installed on the system
Formula values are not calculated during Python processing - recalc.py must be run afterward
Very large spreadsheets may experience performance degradation during processing

use_cases.title: Build Financial Models
use_cases.description: Create discounted cash flow models, valuation spreadsheets, and financial projections with proper color coding.

use_cases.title: Analyze Dataset Exports
use_cases.description: Import CSV or Excel data, perform statistical analysis with pandas, and export formatted results.

use_cases.title: Generate Reports
use_cases.description: Build formatted reports with charts, summaries, and calculated metrics for stakeholders.

prompt_templates.title: Create Simple Spreadsheet
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Excel file named budget.xlsx with monthly revenue and expense data. Add a formula in column C that calculates profit (revenue minus expenses). Apply currency formatting.

prompt_templates.title: Analyze Data
prompt_templates.prompt: Read the file sales_data.xlsx and provide summary statistics including total, average, min, and max for each numerical column.

prompt_templates.title: Recalculate Formulas
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the recalc.py script on financial_model.xlsx to recalculate all formulas and report any errors found.

prompt_templates.title: Build Complex Model
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a three-sheet workbook: assumptions sheet with growth rates and margins, projections sheet with formulas referencing assumptions, and summary sheet with key metrics and charts.

output_examples.input: Create a simple budget spreadsheet with income and expense categories
output: Created budget.xlsx with columns for Category, Description, Amount, and Type
Added 5 sample categories: Software Licenses, Cloud Services, Marketing, Office Supplies, Contractors
Applied currency formatting ($#,##0) with parentheses for negative values
Formula in column C calculates totals automatically

output_examples.input: Analyze the sales data and identify trends
output: Loaded sales_data.xlsx with 1500 rows across 12 columns
Total revenue: $2.4M with monthly growth averaging 8.3%
Peak sales in Q4 (42% of annual revenue)
Top 3 products account for 67% of total sales

best_practices: Always use Excel formulas instead of hardcoded values to keep spreadsheets dynamic and updateable
Place assumptions (growth rates, margins) in separate cells with clear references in formulas
Run recalc.py after creating or modifying spreadsheets with formulas to verify zero errors
anti_patterns: Hardcoding calculated values instead of using Excel formulas
Opening files with data_only=True mode when you need to preserve formulas
Forgetting to run recalc.py after creating formula-based spreadsheets

faq.question: What file formats are supported?
faq.answer: Supports .xlsx, .xlsm, .csv, and .tsv files. Best results with .xlsx for full formula and formatting support.

faq.question: What are the file size limits?
faq.answer: Openpyxl supports large files but may slow down. Use read_only mode for files over 10MB. Consider splitting very large datasets.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with other tools?
faq.answer: Works with pandas for data analysis, matplotlib for charts, and LibreOffice for formula recalculation. No external API calls required.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All processing happens locally. Files are only read from and written to locations you specify. No data leaves your system.

faq.question: Why are formulas not calculating immediately?
faq.answer: Openpyxl preserves formulas as text strings. Run recalc.py to calculate all values using LibreOffice. Script returns JSON with any errors.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual Excel work?
faq.answer: Automates repetitive tasks, ensures consistent formatting, enables programmatic data analysis, and catches formula errors systematically. Not a replacement for Excel.
